Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: P2C2--Paleoclimate Reanalysis: A New View of Past Climates
Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative project aims to produce a Paleoclimate Reanalysis - a statistically robust gridded reconstruction of climate spanning the last 25,000 years - using a data assimilation technique widely used in the meteorological community in order to combine information from climate models and proxies to reconstruct gridded climate fields. The Reanalysis will be used to test hypotheses regarding the response of the tropical Walker circulation and the major monsoon systems to changing climate background states and the origin of low-frequency (centennial to millennial-scale) variability in the Earth's climate system. The specific goal is to test hypotheses regarding the behavior of the tropical climate system under cold and warm climates and to document and identify the dynamical origin of centennial-to millennial-scale climate variability.

The Paleoclimate Reanalysis will be available to the wider science community and could provide a community benchmark to benefit research across multiple disciplines. This project will support a graduate student and postdoctoral candidate as well as involve substantial undergraduate participation in the form of data collection and analysis. This project also support a new partnership with the Girl Power program to develop science education and outreach opportunities for middle school girls in a Tucson public school.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project successfully developed a data assimilation method for reconstructing climate changes in the geological past. Data assimilation is a technique commonly used in weather forecasting, but here we adapted it to "hindcast" ancient climate changes. The technique uses information from both paleoclimate data and climate model simulations.

The project focused on reconstructing climate changes that occurred during the last 20,000 years. 20,000 years ago, the Earth was in an Ice Age, and there were large ice sheets covering North America and Europe. Climate scientists have studied this last ice age extensively, but there was still debate about how cold the planet was. Using our technique, we determined that the last Ice Age was -6˚C (-11˚F) colder than today. We used this new estimate of glacial cooling to calculate Earth's climate sensitivity, which is the temperature response to a doubling of CO2. Our result, 3.4˚C per CO2 doubling, is consistent with many state-of-the-art climate models, and also rules out a low sensitivity during glacial climates.

The data assimilation method allows us to make full maps of ancient climates. You can see an example of the Last Glacial Maximum in the attached image.

We also reconstructed the temperature history of planet Earth from 20,000 years to present day. We are currently analyzing this reconstruction to learn about how tropical and high latitudes climates evolved through the transition between the last Ice Age and warmer Holocene (the last 10,000 years).

This project supported postdoctoral scholars, graduate students, and undergraduate students at the University of Arizona (Tucson, AZ).
